Market Summary
 ãƒ»BTC rebounded into the $97,000 range, with $100k as the next key level where psychology, supply, and derivatives converge
 ãƒ»U.S. spot Bitcoin ETFs recorded large daily inflows (around +$750M), improving upside conditions
 ãƒ»However, profit-taking and overhead supply tend to appear just below $100k, making upside temporarily heavy

â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•â€•
On-Chain & Technical Trends
 ãƒ»The most critical resistance is $100k; a breakout requires sustained ETF inflows and strong spot volume
 ãƒ»Lower exchange balances point to tightening supply, supporting dip-buying behavior
 ãƒ»This rally has been largely short-liquidation driven, implying fast moves but a higher chance of upper wicks
 ãƒ»Open Interest is recovering after a reset: gradual increases are healthy, sharp spikes raise liquidation risk
 ãƒ»If futures selling pressure stays muted, price may consolidate sideways near highs (a constructive setup)
 ãƒ»Increased movement from dormant or older coins adds short-term supply and caps upside momentum
 ãƒ»Near-term support sits around $95k, followed by $92kâ€“93k; a break below risks a return to range trading
 ãƒ»Conclusion: Structure is bullish, but the $100k area demands confirmation from flows and leverage discipline

Sentiment

 ãƒ»As $100k approaches, FOMO can ignite quickly, but failure to break may trigger fast disappointment selling
 ãƒ»Retail participation remains fragile, though continued retail exit can paradoxically lighten selling pressure
 ãƒ»Any sharp ETF outflow, even for a day, could accelerate downside as leverage rebuilds
 ãƒ»Geopolitical headlines may spark brief risk-off moves; dip-buying strength will define the trend
 ãƒ»Altcoins face higher idiosyncratic risks (outages, protocol issues), limiting broad index rallies
 ãƒ»Capital is concentrating on themes such as regulation, payments, infrastructure, and bank adoption
 ãƒ»Conclusion: Fear is fading, but upside follow-through requires confirmation rather than emotion

 ãƒ»Even when equities are strong, crypto remains primarily driven by ETF and spot demand

Overall Assessment
ETF inflows and liquidation-driven momentum place BTC in a moderately bullish phase with a clear test of $100k ahead. Still, resistance near the milestone is heavy, and upside continuation depends on sustained ETF inflows and spot volume. Dips are likely to be bought, but as leverage rebuilds, volatility will increaseâ€”position sizing and risk control remain essential.

 ãƒ»Headline-driven volatility from geopolitics and policy statements

Only then will they use other strategies to reach their main objective.

Our RWA Mindshare series tracks weekly momentum across real-world asset projects using KaitoAI's 30-day rolling analysis. This week, we're deep-diving into Algorand - a long-standing Layer 1 blockchain known for its performance, academic roots, and strong institutional credibility.

Algorand wasn't built exclusively for RWAs, but it's become a dominant player nonetheless. Algorand was designed as a general-purpose blockchain, optimized for fast finality, low fees, and predictable execution. Its Pure Proof-of-Stake consensus, carbon-negative footprint, and conservative engineering choices have made it a trusted infrastructure layer for enterprises, governments, and financial institutions.

Algorand's approach works exceptionally well for tokenized securities and government-backed assets where protocol-native compliance is critical.

At Mavryk, we're taking a different approach. 

Algorand adapted a general-purpose blockchain to support RWAs through thoughtful protocol design. We built a purpose-built RWA Layer 1 from the ground up, with compliance, identity, governance, and settlement primitives embedded directly into the protocol. 

Because we make our own market and focus on real estate and income-producing RWAs, our assets can trade in continuous, 24/7 primary and secondary markets without relying on fragmented off-chain systems.

Let's check in with @token_works â€” the dev studio behind:

PunkStrategy (Sept. 2025) â€” Introduced $PNKSTR with a 10% trading fee. The protocol accumulates ETH, buys the cheapest CryptoPunk it can, and relists it for a 20% premium, 'round and 'round. Upon any sales, all proceeds are used to burn $PNKSTR.

NFTStrategy (Sept. 2025) â€” Extended the $PNKSTR playbook to a curated set of top NFT collections like Bored Ape Yacht Club, Pudgy Penguins, and Chimpers, routing a portion of revenue back to original creators via onchain royalties.

TokenStrategy (Dec. 2025) â€” Unveiled a permissionless launchpad for deploying strategy tokens for NFT collections or ERC-20s you've created, debuting Recursive Strategies that buy and burn their own tokens.

~~ Analysis by @wmpeaster ~~

Accordingly, TokenWorks is a team to watch in 2026, and they're already off to a hot start. Today they announced that anyone can now deploy any ERC-20 strategy they want.

This matters because previously the TokenStrategy platform would only let you deploy such a strategy if you controlled the underlying ERC-20 smart contract. However, projects renouncing control of their coins for immutability is a common pattern in the Ethereum ecosystem.

TokenWorks just "upgraded the TokenStrategy launcher to handle this case [...] If the Strategy is not deployed by the owner, the creator fee is also used to buy the underlying token."

Yet TokenWorks has something even bigger in the works for later this month: the arrival of IndexStrategies.

Like the name suggests, IndexStrategies will focus on buying a range of specific assets instead of just buying CryptoPunks, or just buying Bored Apes, etc.

The first IndexStrategy will be $AB500STR, which will accumulate works from Art Blocks 500, the 500 official generative art releases Art Blocks has facilitated.

$AB500STR will rotate through all @artblocks_io  collections in sequence, starting with Chromie Squiggles. Each collection gets a three-day purchase window. If an NFT is acquired, or the window expires, the strategy advances to the next collection. Once all 500 projects have been cycled through, the loop restarts.

Like other NFT strategies, $AB500STR enforces a 10% trading fee, split between the strategy, buy-and-burns of $PNKSTR (as the ecosystem token), and creator royalties. The main wrinkle? The royalties are distributed evenly across the +300 AB500 artists instead of just going to one collection creator.

When sales occur after relistings, proceeds will be used to buy and burn $AB500STR, and this earn, buy, sell, and burn loop will run for as long as Ethereum runs.

This kind of setup is ideal for someone who wants long-term exposure to some of Ethereum's most iconic gen art collections without breaking the bank or manually curating buys.

$AB500STR is just the first of the IndexStrategies releases. In time, this model could be expanded in all sorts of directions. Consider tokenized PokÃ©mon cards. Imagine a $BS1999STR that accumulates across the 102 cards of the legendary 1999 PokÃ©mon Base Set series, all onchain.

We'll have to see where things go from here, but IndexStrategies do point the way to new cultural experiments. TokenWorks flips speculation so it's taxed into accumulation and royalties. Traders fund collectors, and artists get paid even when marketplaces don't enforce royalties. That's a really interesting dynamic worth tracking closely in the months ahead.

That context mattered - because the question wasnâ€™t whether the vault works, but how it should scale responsibly.
One thing was made clear early on:
Optional, user-managed insurance doesnâ€™t scale for actively managed vaults.

As vaults grow and allocations shift across protocols, expecting users to separately manage cover breaks down fast.
As @MontBlancDeFi (Head of BD, @NexusMutual) put it:

â€œInstead of thinking about a â€˜covered vaultâ€™, itâ€™s more accurate to say a vault with embedded cover. The coverage is part of the vaultâ€™s design.â€

That distinction matters.
In High Gainâ€™s case, coverage is:

â› Taken by the vault curator, not users
â› Applied at the portfolio level, not per position
â› Designed to exist alongside the vault, not as an add-on

Users donâ€™t opt in. They donâ€™t manage anything separately.

As @TokenData (COO, @NexusMutual) explained:

â€œBy embedding it at the vault level, all of this is simplified. The average depositor doesnâ€™t have to think about whether theyâ€™re covered.â€
